facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 30 of 1968 is an appeal by special leave from the Judgment Order dated 14th October 1966 of the Bombay High Court in W.P. Spl. Appln. 1019 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 30 of 1968. Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment Order dated the 14th October, 1966 of the Bombay High Court in W.P.  Spl. Appln. of 1019 of 1965 .

facts.text: The disputed land comprises 15 acres and 14 Gunthas in Osmanabad in Survey No. 206/B.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant has endeavoured on one ground or the other to get the 15 acres and 14 Gunthas of land in Osmanabad which at one time formed part of the erstwhile State of Hyderabad and eventually came to be a part of the State of Maharasht

facts.text: The land at one time formed part of the erstwhile State of Hyderabad and came to be part of the State of Maharashtra.

anchor.surface_text: ra. The disputed land is companyprised in Survey No. 206/B. There is numberdispute that the appellant was the Inamdar of this land. The Hyderabad Abolition of Inams and Cash Grants Act, 1954 being Hyderabad Act No. VIII

facts.text: There is no dispute that the appellant was the Inamdar of the land.

anchor.surface_text: of 1955  hereinafter called the Abolition of Inams Act,  came into force on its publication in the gazette on the 20th July, 1955. The Abolition of Inams Act was amended by the Hyderabad Abolition of Inams  Amendment  Act, 1956

facts.text: Hyderabad Abolition of Inams and Cash Grants Act, 1954 (Hyderabad Act No. VIII of 1955) came into force on 20th July 1955.

anchor.surface_text: and was further amended by Bombay Act 64 of 1959 which came into force on 1st July, 1960. It is numberlonger in companytroversy that the Abolition of Inams Act became applicable to the appellants Inam by virtue of the amended provisions on 1-7-1960

facts.text: Abolition of Inams Act amended by Hyderabad Abolition of Inams Amendment Act 1956 and Bombay Act 64 of 1959 effective 1st July 1960.

anchor.surface_text: as a result of which under Section 3 appellants Inam was abolished and vested in the State. Upon its vesting, certain companysequences followed which will be adverted to hereinafter in this judgment.

facts.text: Abolition of Inams Act became applicable to appellant's Inam on 1-7-1960, abolishing the Inam and vesting it in the State under Section 3.

anchor.surface_text: The first round of litigation started by the appellant against respondent number 1 treating him as his tenant under the Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Land Act, 1950, Hyderabad Act No. XXI of 1950  hereinafter called the Tenancy Act  was started by the appella

facts.text: Appellant served notice on first respondent under section 44 of Tenancy Act purporting to terminate tenancy by 31st December 1958.

anchor.surface_text: nt by serving a numberice on the first respondent under section 44 of the said Tenancy Act. The appellant claimed in that proceeding that he bonafide required the land for cultivating it personally and hence after service of numberice purporting to terminate

facts.text: Appellant filed application on 18-3-1959 for possession under section 32(2) of Tenancy Act.

anchor.surface_text: the tenancy by the 31st day of December, 1958 him proceeded to file an application on 18-3-1959 for possession of the land under section 32 2  of the Tenancy Act.

facts.text: Naib Tehsildar, Land Reforms, Osmanabad rejected appellant's resumption application on 22-10-1959.

anchor.surface_text: The Naib Tehsildar, Land Reforms, Osmanabad rejected the resumption application of the appellant by his order dated 22-10-1959 holding against him on merits that he has made out numbercase for termination of the tenancy.

facts.text: Deputy Collector Land Reforms Osmanabad allowed appellant's appeal on 25-5-1962.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant went up in appeal which was allowed by the Deputy Collector Land Reforms Osmanabad by his order dated 25-5-1962.

facts.text: Revenue Tribunal allowed revision of respondent No.1 on 15-10-1962.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent number 1 went up in revision. The Revenue Tribunal allowed the revision of respondent number 1 by its order made on 15-10-1962.

facts.text: Revenue Tribunal held that respondent No.1 acquired rights of occupant under section 6(1)(a) of Abolition of Inams Act after abolition and vesting.

anchor.surface_text: It took the view accepting a new stand taken on behalf of the tenant respondent,no. 1 that after the abolition and vesting of the appellants Inam the said respondent who was in possession of the land companyered by the Inam as a tenant holding from the Jnamdar had acquired all the rights of an occupant in respect of such land under section 6  1   a  of the Abolition of Inams Act.

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed Special Civil Application No. 1881 of 1962 on 26-9-1963 under Article 227.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant moved the High Court of Bombay under Article 227 of the Constitution of India in Special Civil Application No. 1881 of 1962. Agreeing with the view of the Revenue Tribunal the Special Civil Application was dismissed by the High Court on 26-9-1963.

facts.text: Deputy Collector held on 30-11-1962 that land was Watan land granted for service as Mahajan, vesting on 1st July 1960, possession entitled to occupancy under section 6(1).

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Collector decided the matter in the first instance by his order dated 30-11-1962. He held that the land was granted to the appellant for his service as Mahajan it companyld, therefore, be deemed to be a Watan land. He further held that the provisions of section 6 of Abolition of Inams Act were applicable and the date of vesting of the Inam was 1st July, 1960 and number 20th July, 1955.

facts.text: Tehsildar held on 15-7-1963 that respondent No.1 was tenant in possession on vesting date and acquired occupant rights under section 6(1).

anchor.surface_text: The Tehsildar by his order dated 15-7- 1963 decided the matter in favour of the first respondent and held him to be a tenant in possession of the land on the date of vesting of the Inam and hence a person acquiring the rights of an occupant under section 6 1 .

facts.text: State Government rejected appellant's appeal under section 2A(2) communicated by letter dated 27th November 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed an appeal before the State Government under section 2A 2  of the Abolition of Inams Act from the decision of the Tehsildar. The rejection of the appellants appeal by the State Government was companymunicated to him by a letter dated 27th November, 1964

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed Special Civil Application No. 1019 of 1966 on 14-10-1966.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenged the order of the State Government in Special Civil Application No. 1019 of 1966 under Articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution of India in the Bombay High Court. A Bench of the High Court dismissed his Writ Application by its judgment and order dated 1.4-10- 1966.

facts.text: Respondent No.1 was admittedly the appellant's tenant.

anchor.surface_text: In the present proceeding the High Court pointed out that respondent number 1 was admittedly the appellants tenant.

facts.text: Respondent No.1 was in cultivating possession of the land paying rent to appellant since long before vesting.

anchor.surface_text: The fact remains that respondent number 1 was in cultivating possession of the land in question paying rent to the appellant since long before the vesting of the Inam. It companyld number but be in his capacity as a tenant of the appellant.

facts.text: Tenancy did not terminate by service of notice under section 44 and filing application under section 32(2); terminated only on order for possession.

anchor.surface_text: Reading the wordings of sections 44 1  and 32 2  of the Tenancy Act it was number possible to accept the companytention put forward on behalf of the appellant that by mere service of numberice and the filing of application for possession the tenancy had some to an end.

facts.text: Respondent No.1 was tenant in possession on 1st July 1960 when Inam vested, acquiring rights of occupant under section 6(1) of Abolition of Inams Act.

anchor.surface_text: He was a tenant when the Inam of the appellant vested in the State on the 1st of July, 1960. Indisputably, he was in possession of the land on that date. Consequently he acquired the rights of an occupant under section 6 1  of the Abolition of Inams Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal with costs to Respondent No.1.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons stated above the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts to Respondent No. 1 above.

holdings.text: It was not necessary for the State Government to give a personal hearing to the appellant or his authorised representative before disposal of his appeal under section 2A(2) of the Abolition of Inams Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment none of the points urged on behalf of the appellant is fit to succeed. It was not necessary for the State Government to give a personal hearing to the appellant or his authorised representative before disposal of his appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No factual adjudication involved; decision on points of law only.

holdings.text: The State Government ought to have disposed of the appeal by a speaking order, but absence thereof not sufficient to set aside and remit in this case.

anchor.surface_text: As has been repeatedly pointed out by this Court the State Government ought to have disposed of the statutory appeal of the appellant filed under section 2A(2) of the Abolition of Inams Act by a speaking order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Courts insist on reasons when challenged under Arts 226/227, but High Court rightly not remitted as no facts to adjudicate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant previously invoked Tenancy Act treating respondent as tenant; cannot change position.

holdings.text: Tenancy does not terminate merely by service of notice under s.44(1) and filing application under s.32(2); terminates only on possession order per rule 28(5).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of sections; confirmed by rule 28(5) and Full Bench precedent in Dattatraya.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed possession as tenant on vesting; direct application of s.6(1).

precedents.citation: Dattatraya Sadashiv Dhond v. Ganpati Raghu Gaoli 1 67 Bombay Law Reporter, 521

anchor.surface_text: A full Bench of the Bombay High Court in Dattatraya Sadashiv Dhond v. Ganpati Raghu Gaoli 1 expressed the view at page 529 The manner in which a tenancy is to be terminated is, however, laid down in section 44. Under this section the tenancy terminates when after giving the requisite numberice the landholder makes an application for possession to the Tehsildar. Thereafter the tenants possession is number unlawful, but it is number held by him as a tenant. He has an estate in possession, which he will lose if the Tehsildar makes an order in favour of the landholder. If, however, the Tehsildar rejects the application of the landholder, the termination of tenancy by the-landholder will become ineffective. The tenancy will revive and the tenant will companytinue in  1  67 Bombay Law Reporter, 521.

precedents.case_name: Dattatraya Sadashiv Dhond v. Ganpati Raghu Gaoli
precedents.cited_proposition: Tenancy under section 44 of the Tenancy Act terminates when the landholder gives notice and makes an application for possession to the Tehsildar; thereafter tenant holds not as tenant but with estate lost only if order for possession made; if rejected, tenancy revives.
precedents.cited_holding: The manner in which a tenancy is to be terminated is, however, laid down in section 44. Under this section the tenancy terminates when after giving the requisite notice the landholder makes an application for possession to the Tehsildar. Thereafter the tenants possession is no unlawful, but it is no held by him as a tenant. He has an estate in possession, which he will lose if the Tehsildar makes an order in favour of the landholder. If, however, the Tehsildar rejects the application of the landholder, the termination of tenancy by the-landholder will become ineffective. The tenancy will revive and the tenant will continue in possession as if his tenancy had no been terminated.
